choices.D: review of SIDs in the Registry

questions.question_text: What method of computer forensics will allow you to trace all ever-established user accounts on a Windows 2000 sever the course of its lifetime?

discussion.content: Answer shd be D. review of SIDs in the Registry
Answer is D. Option C is totally out of it

To trace all user accounts that have ever been established on a Windows 2000 server over its lifetime, you would need to review the Security Identifiers (SIDs) in the Registry. Each user account on a Windows system is assigned a unique SID, which is stored in the Registry. By examining these SIDs, you can identify all user accounts that have been created on the system.

Therefore, the correct answer is:

D. review of SIDs in the Registry

Selected Answer: D
SID registry identifies all history user account in Windows.

The Security Identifier (SID) is a unique identifier assigned to each user account in Windows. By reviewing the SIDs in the Registry, a forensic investigator can trace all ever-established user accounts on a Windows 2000 server over the course of its lifetime

Selected Answer: D
Answer shd be D. review of SIDs in the Registry
The answere is definitely The review of SIDs in the Reg. D
Answer should be D. As user account are assigned a unique SID and SID are not reused.

questions.question_text: Which response organization tracks hoaxes as well as viruses?

discussion.content:
As per https://www.govinfo.gov/ the following description for each:
18 U.S.C. 1029 - Fraud and related activity in connection with access devices.
18 U.S.C. 1362 - Communication lines, stations or systems.
18 U.S.C. 2511 - Interception and disclosure of wire, oral, or electronic communications prohibited.
18 U.S.C. 2703 - Required disclosure of customer communications or records
So 'A' is the answer.

questions.question_text: Which federal computer crime law specifically refers to fraud and related activity in connection with access devices like routers?
In a FAT32 system, a 123 KB file will use how many sectors?

discussion.content: 512Bytes make 1 Sector ; 123KB=123*1024=125952Bytes >> 125952/512 = 246 Sectors. No answer in this case

number of sectors = (123 * 1024 bytes * 1 sector )/ 512 bytes =246 sectors 
since in this case FAT32 will contain 512 bytes per sector.

choices.D: The attacker has installed a backdoor
choices.B: The attacker has scanned and exploited the system using Buffer Overflow
choices.A: The attacker has conducted a network sweep on port 111
choices.C: The attacker has used a Trojan on port 32773

questions.question_text:
A honey pot deployed with the IP 172.16.1.108 was compromised by an attacker. Given below is an excerpt from a Snort binary capture of the attack. Decipher the activity carried out by the attacker by studying the log. Please note that you are required to infer only what is explicit in the excerpt.
(Note: The student is being tested on concepts learnt during passive OS fingerprinting, basic TCP/IP connection concepts and the ability to read packet signatures from a sniff dump.)
03/15-20:21:24.107053 211.185.125.124:3500 -> 172.16.1.108:111
TCP TTL:43 TOS:0x0 ID:29726 IpLen:20 DgmLen:52 DF
***A**** Seq: 0x9B6338C5 Ack: 0x5820ADD0 Win: 0x7D78 TcpLen: 32
TCP Options (3) => NOP NOP TS: 23678634 2878772 =+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=
+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=
03/15-20:21:24.452051 211.185.125.124:789 -> 172.16.1.103:111
UDP TTL:43 TOS:0x0 ID:29733 IpLen:20 DgmLen:84

Len: 64 -
01 0A 8A 0A 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 02 00 01 86 A0 . .............
00 00 00 02 00 00 00 03 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 ................
00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 01 86 B8 00 00 00 01 . ..............
00 00 00 11 00 00 00 00 ........
=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=+=
03/15-20:21:24.730436 211.185.125.124:790 -> 172.16.1.103:32773
UDP TTL:43 TOS:0x0 ID:29781 IpLen:20 DgmLen:1104

Len: 1084 -
47 F7 9F 63 00 00 00 00 00 00 00 02 00 01 86 B8

discussion.content:
I should disagree with the answer. Based on the log, the most explicit activity is:
B. The attacker has scanned and exploited the system using Buffer Overflow
The large UDP packet to port 32773 strongly suggests a buffer overflow exploit.

Per my understanding, a network sweep would involve scanning multiple IP addresses, but here, the attacker targets specific ports on the same subnet.
To select something other than A you need more specific information about the attack type, in the output.

hard to argue on a sweep over port 111 due to the last line 03/15-20:21:24.730436 211.185.125.124:790 -> 172.16.1.103:32773
but I will agree with this answer as the other choices won't work
